channel.title: ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration on ANT 6973, Spring 2021
channel.description: Recent content in ANT 6973: Data Visualization and Exploration on ANT 6973, Spring 2021

item.description: ANT 6973 DataCamp Dashboard Throughout the course we will be using DataCamp, a platform that provides an interactive way to learn how to use R to create visualizations and carry out data analysis. Invite link: https://www.datacamp.com/groups/shared_links/860db90029f1891286789d3ece4f95d11df40484

item.title: Policies
item.description: Course Description This course introduces theory and practical skills for managing and displaying quantitative information so that visual stories can be found and communicated effectively. We will cover principles of tidy data, strategies for data exploration, and principles of visual presentation. We will use the R computing environment, but no prior programming experience is required. The emphasis is on gaining practical skills that will empower students to answer questions with data.
ANT 6973

tutorial for Data Science Triad: GitHub, RMarkdown, Travis-CI rstudio Watch: RStudio IDE, Part I Read: readings/setup.md Prerequisites Running R code RStudio Cheat sheet (for reference) rmarkdown Watch: Reports with RMarkdown (by Garrett Grolemund) Read: Introduction [r4ds-27.1] R Markdown [r4ds-27.2] Code chunks [r4ds-27.4] git Watch: DataCamp Lesson: RStudio IDE, Part II, Chapter 2: Version Control (by Garrett Grolemund). vis.1 Watch: Tidyverse Chapter 2: Data Visualization (David Robinson) (Yes, we’re starting with Chapter 2, we’ll go back to Chapter 1 soon).

item.title: "Reshaping Data
item.description:
Forgot to post this earlier. Don’t worry about reading before class, just take a look at it some time.
“Tidy Data” by Hadley Wickham. Ignore all the R code thatt you encounter, as bascially all of it has now been superseded by newer tidyverse functions. This was Wickham’s early “tidy tools” manifesto; it provided guiding principles and a framework for developing the tidyverse.

item.title: Cheat Sheets
item.description: You can find these and more at https://www.rstudio.com/resources/cheatsheets/.

item.title: Color, Saving Output, and Composing Multiple Plots
item.description: No assignment for this week! Finish up Small Project 1 and any other assignments that you haven’t completed. We will have some class time on March. 17 for any help or questions related to Small Project 1.

item.title: Color, Saving Output, and Composing Multiple Plots
item.description: Read Making effective use of color Wilke, Ch. 4: Color scales Wilke, Ch. 19: Common pitfalls of color use Saving plots as image files R4DS, Ch. 28.7: Saving your plots Wilke, Ch. 27: Understanding the most commonly used image file formats Composing multiple plots Wilke, Ch. 21: Multi-panel figures Patchwork: Getting started Color Resources Color Brewer: Color advice and a great set of color palettes; r package: RColorBrewer.

item.title: Color, Saving Output, and Composing Multiple Plots
item.description: Week 8 slides: 07_color-output-composing.pdf ( 6.4 MB)

item.title: Color, Saving Output, and Geospatial Data
item.description: Read Visualizing Geospatial Data Wilke, Ch. 15: Visualizing geospatial data Why all world maps are wrong XKCD Map Projections Extra Software and R Packages for Geospatial Data To use the powerful spatial functions in R, some extra software will be required. R doesn’t do all the geographic calculations by itself. It relies on some other software that runs behind the scenes. Depending on your computer and how it’s configured, some of you may able to get this working right away, whereas others may need some additional steps as detailed below.

item.title: Data Import
item.description: To complete this week’s activities, you will need a new package, in addition to a few you already have installed (readr, readxl). install.packages("janitor") Data for in-class activities Example messy spreadsheet containing biographical data for various people: deaths.xlsx Atmospheric ozone measurements of the southern hemisphere collected by NASA’s NIMBUS-7 satellite in October 1985: nimbus.csv R markdown template for ozone activity ozone.Rmd Complete on your own Spreadsheets

item.title: Data Import
item.description: Read Organizing Data Peruse the website “Data Organization in Spreadsheets”, much of which has been written up in a journal article: Broman KW, Woo KH (2018) Data organization in spreadsheets. The American Statistician 78:2–10. PDF ( 3.9 MB) Importing Data R4DS, Ch. 10: Tibbles (short) R4DS, Ch. 11.2: Data Import, “Getting started” I suggest working through the exercises to help you understand the code.

item.title: Data Import
item.description: Week 10 slides: 09_data-import.pdf ( 4.0 MB)

item.title: Data Manipulation 1
item.description: To complete this week’s activities, you will need to install the “development” version of tidyr. devtools::install_github("tidyverse/tidyr") Important note: As we discussed in class on March 21, the wide/long reshaping functions were in flux when we learned about them. Since that time, the authors have settled on slightly different names: pivot_longer() and pivot_wider(). It looks like these names are going to stick. All course materials have been updated accordingly. You will not see this change unless you reinstall the development version of tidyr by (re-)running the command devtools::install_github("tidyverse/tidyr").

item.title: Data Manipulation 1: Filter, Arrange, Select, Mutate
item.description: Read R4DS, 5.1–5.5: Data Transformation: dplyr basic verbs: filter(), arrange(), select(), and mutate(). Optional further reading. Introduction to dplyr: many code examples Modern Dive, Chapter 3, 3.1–3.2 and 3.5–3.6, 3.8: Data Wrangling: Similar to assigned reading but organized differently. Some might find the text easier to follow.

item.title: Data Manipulation 2
item.description: Companion to in-class activities summarise-activities.Rmd (Nothing to turn in!)

item.title: Data Manipulation 2: Grouped Summaries, Filters, and Mutates
item.description: Read R4DS, 5.6–5.7: Data Transformation: dplyr basic verbs: summarise, group_by, and new ways to use mutate and filter. Optional further reading (same as last week). Introduction to dplyr: many code examples Modern Dive, Chapter 4: Data Wrangling: Similar to assigned reading but organized differently. Might be a little easier to follow?

item.title: Final Project
item.description: Due date: May 05 by the end of the day (11:59:59 pm)Description The final project should essentially look like any of our small projects, but with two key differences: You will decide on the data set to use, and I especially encourage you to find and/or use a data set that is related to your thesis topic. If this is not possible, I can help you find a data set on a topic relevant to your interests.

item.title: Introduction & Setup
item.description: Read Preface of Healy’s Data Visualization. Introduction of Wickham’s R for Data Science (or “R4DS”).

item.title: Introduction & Setup
item.description: Week 1 slides: Introduction and setup ( 14.2 MB)

item.title: Introduction and Setup
item.description:
Complete in Class To start becoming familiar with R, we’re going to complete some interactive, self-paced lessons using swirl.
Steps:
Open up RStudio, type the following in the console pane (next to the > symbol), and press Enter. This should install the ‘swirl’ package for R. That means the package files have been downloaded and saved to your computer. install.packages("swirl") But to actually use the functions in the swirl package, we need to load the package into our current R session.

Do this in console, not in your R Markdown file! install.packages("nycflights13") Companion to in-class activities two-table-operations.Rmd (Nothing to turn in!) Complete before next class NYC Flights Instructions: Download the R Markdown file and data files below Insert your code where indicated Email me your knitted .html output. nyc-flights.

item.title: Modules
item.description: Module Candidate paper Data Format Technical skills timeline Climate Change Petit et al. (1999) Tabular data Parsing tabular data, visualization (readr, ggplot2) directions_boat Overfishing Worm et al. (2006) Relational databases groups, joins, filters. SQL (dplyr, tidyr) bug_report Ecological Simulations May (1974) memory Simulated data Functional programming, (purrr) my_location Range shifts Pinsky et al.

item.title: Modules
item.description: Climate Change Tabular data What is the evidence for a changing climate? In this unit, we will examine some of the most important indicators of global climate change: including CO2 concentration, global mean temperature, sea level rise, land ice sheet melt, and arctic sea ice cover. We will wrangle a wide range of tabular data file formats used by NOAA and other agencies and introduce the fundamentals of data visualization with ggplot2 and data processing with basic functions from the readr, tidyr, and dplyr packages as we seek to replicate the principle results of climate change over the last decades and also the past thousands of years.

item.title: R Basics and R Markdown
item.description: Setup To complete this week’s activities, you must have a few packages installed. You can do so by running the commands below in your R console (only needs to be done once). install.packages("tidyverse") install.packages("here") install.packages("rmarkdown") Complete in Class Markdown CV Instructions: Create a basic CV in markdown (you can make stuff up!) What to include Top-level header should be your name Include contact info: phone, email, and link to some website.

item.title: R Basics and R Markdown
item.description: Read ModernDive Ch. 1: Getting Started with Data in R (section 1.1 is review, the rest may be more useful) Healy Section 2.3: Things to know about R Chapter 2 of R Markdown: The Definitive Guide (skip the long video at the end and the example applications) Skim Tidyverse style guide, Ch. 1 and Ch. 2. Consistent style is an important element of communication and collaboration.

item.title: R Basics and R Markdown
item.description: Read ModernDive Ch. 1: Getting Started with Data in R Healy Section 2.3: Things to know about R Chapter 2 of R Markdown: The Definitive Guide (you can skip the long video at the end and the example applications) Tidyverse style guide, Ch. 1 and Ch. 2. Consistent style is an important element of communication and collaboration. SKIM over the sections 1. Files and 2.

item.description: Week 2 slides: R Basics and R Markdown ( 5.5 MB)

Complete on your own Tidy Data Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below Insert your code where indicated Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, and upload your knitted .html output and the .Rmd file to Blackboard.
school-earnings.csv tidy-data.Rmd tidy-data-solutions.html (for reference—code removed.)

item.title: Reshaping Data
item.description: Week 11 slides: 09_reshaping-data.pdf ( 2.6 MB)

item.title: Small Project 1: Ape Teeth
item.description: Due date: Mar. 17 by the end of the day (11:59:59 pm) Introduction In this small project, you will think of conceptual questions to ask of a data set of ape teeth measurements and create plots to answer those questions. Description of the data Download: - ape_teeth.csv Data source: http://anthropologicaldata.free.fr/ Columns Species: ape species the tooth belongs to, including: Gorilla gorilla (Western gorilla) Pan troglodytes (Common chimpanzee) Pongo pygmaeus (Bornean orangutan) Site: where specimen is located Specimen: specimen ID number Sex: Male or Female Source: where data come from Tooth: name of tooth (see below).

item.title: Small Project 2
item.description: Due date: Apr. 18 by the end of the day (11:59:59 pm)Introduction In this small project, you will think of conceptual questions to ask of one or more data sets. Because I think some of you disliked the ape_teeth data set from small project 1, this time I’m providing several different data sets that can be used. All your questions can be from one data set, or you can ask different questions of different data sets.

item.title: Two-table Operations: Joins and Set operations
item.description: Read Modern Dive, Chapter 4.7: “Join Data Frames”: A concise overview of join verbs in dplyr. R4DS, 13: Relational Data: More detailed, with many examples. Also covers set operations.

item.title: Visualization Basics
item.description: Complete in Class Mammalian sleep dataset: msleep Description of dataset From V. M. Savage and G. B. West. A quantitative, theoretical framework for understanding mammalian sleep. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 104 (3):1051-1056, 2007. Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, submit the .md and .html files for your activity in Blackboard. msleep.Rmd msleep_solutions.html (for reference only—finished plots with no code!

item.title: Visualization Challenges
item.description: Catch-up work Work on Small Project 2! Get caught up will any other assignments that you haven’t completed. This includes: 9 DataCamp chapters. msleep pies baboon-activities babynames maps ozone spreadsheets tidy-data data-manip1 If you’re all caught up, practice your data manipulation and plotting skills by working on the two small challenges below. I’ll post solutions after class is over. 1. Sex differences in mortality over time in Western Europe Data:

item.title: Visualizing Amounts and Parts of a Whole
item.description: Complete in Class Baboon Activity Budgets (if we run out of time, complete between now and class on Feb. 17) Instructions: Download the R Markdown file below, insert your code where indicated, submit the .Rmd and .html files for your activity in Blackboard. baboon-activities.Rmd baboon_acts_2000.csv (data file) baboon-activities-solutions.html (for reference—finished plots with no code!) If you get stuck, please email me for some help!

item.title: Visualizing Amounts and Parts of a Whole

item.title: Visualizing Distributions and Uncertainty
item.description: Read Wilke, Ch. 7: Visualizing distributions: Histograms and density plots Wilke, Ch. 9: Visualizing many distributions at once Wilke, Ch. 16: Visualizing uncertainty Popovich and Pearce, “It’s Not Your Imagination. Summers Are Getting Hotter.” Matthew Conlen, “Kernel Density Estimation” Nicole Torres (2010), “Why It’s So Hard for Us to Visualize Uncertainty” Robert Kosara (2017), “Communicating Uncertainty When Lives Are on the Line”
